The Role of Coarse Woody Debris and Microtopography in Wetland Function: A Review and Recommendations to Improve Wetland Restoration
The Role of Coarse Woody Debris and Microtopography in Wetland
Function: A Review and Recommendations to Improve Wetland
Restoration

Ninth Annual Wetlands and Watersheds Workshop
Ninth Annual Wetlands and Watersheds Workshop

Atlantic City, NJ
Atlantic City, NJ

23 October 2006
23 October 2006

Charles A. Rhodes Jr.
Charles A. Rhodes Jr.

U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency

Philadelphia, PA 10103-2029
Philadelphia, PA 10103-2029

rhodes.charles@epa.gov
rhodes.charles@epa.gov

Microtopography for the purpose of this presentation includes the variation in the soil surface caused by natural ecological processes such as:
Microtopography for the purpose of this presentation
includes the variation in the soil surface caused by natural
ecological processes such as:

•Tree mortality whether by uprooting (thereby forming mounds and pits) or mortality in place (e.g., snags).
•Tree mortality whether by uprooting (thereby forming
mounds and pits) or mortality in place (e.g., snags).

•Accumulations of organic material and soil by processes such as tussock formation, shallow rooting, buttressing, etc.
•Accumulations of organic material and soil by processes
such as tussock formation, shallow rooting, buttressing, etc.

•The more constant but less long-lived deposition of large branches and twigs.
•The more constant but less long-lived deposition of large
branches and twigs.

“When the winds tear up a tree by the root, a quantity of loose soil commonly comes up with it and sticks to them (sic) for a time, but at last it drops off and forms a little hillock, which is afterwards augmented by leaves. In this way many holes and mounds are formed.”
“When the winds tear up a tree by the root, a quantity of loose soil
commonly comes up with it and sticks to them (sic) for a time, but at last it
drops off and forms a little hillock, which is afterwards augmented by
leaves. In this way many holes and mounds are formed.”

Kalm, Peter. 1770. Travels in North America. Adolph B. Benson, translator and editor, Wilson-Erickson Inc., New York, NY (1937).
Kalm, Peter. 1770. Travels in North America. Adolph B. Benson, translator
and editor, Wilson-Erickson Inc., New York, NY (1937).

Microtopography may be linked to century-old mounds or recent accumulations by herbaceous vegetation.
Microtopography
may be linked to
century-old
mounds or recent
accumulations by
herbaceous
vegetation.

In many forests large trees are often located on pre-existing windthrow mounds or “butt- hillocks” (soil displaced by the basal growth of trees).
In many forests
large trees are
often located on
pre-existing
windthrow
mounds or “butt-
hillocks” (soil
displaced by the
basal growth of
trees).

Bald Cypress Stump, Lower Mississippi Valley, LA (1986)
Bald Cypress Stump, Lower
Mississippi Valley, LA (1986)

Both standing and breaking kinds of tree death contribute decaying logs and stumps to the forest floor but they may be relatively short-lived when compared to mounds created from the uprooting of trees.
Both standing and breaking kinds of tree death
contribute decaying logs and stumps to the forest
floor but they may be relatively short-lived when
compared to mounds created from the uprooting of
trees.

Most historical pit and mound studies have focused on upland areas, but given the wetland environment, the rate of formation may be more dynamic than in upland areas (e.g., more rapid filling of pits, greater frequency of tree fall).
Most historical pit
and mound studies
have focused on
upland areas, but
given the wetland
environment, the
rate of formation
may be more
dynamic than in
upland areas (e.g.,
more rapid filling
of pits, greater
frequency of tree
fall).

Areal distribution of mounds and pits on four 30 x 100 foot plots. Stippled areas are mounds, darkened areas are pts. From Lyford, W.H., and D. W. MacLean. 1966. Mound and pit microrelief in relation to soil disturbances and tree distribution in New Brunswick, Canada. Harvard For. Pap. 15. 18 pp.

Mound and pit microrelief in relation to soil disturbances and tree distribution in New Brunswick, Canada. Harvard for. Pap. 15. 18 pp. Note: Dark polygons are pits and the light polygons are mounds.

Some plants are established on fallen logs where there is a ready source of organic material. Additionally they are elevated above the prevalent flooding regime. Often as the log decomposes the established trees can withstand deeper, more prolonged flooding.
Some plants are established on fallen logs where there
is a ready source of organic material. Additionally
they are elevated above the prevalent flooding regime.
Often as the log decomposes the established trees can
withstand deeper, more prolonged flooding.

For example, yellow birch (Betula alleghaniensis) is a major codominant tree in northeastern upland and wetland forests. In wetlands, yellow birch seedlings often become established on fallen logs. What appear to be prop roots on mature trees are in fact locations where the “nurse” log has decomposed out from beneath the mature tree.
For example, yellow birch (Betula alleghaniensis) is a
major codominant tree in northeastern upland and
wetland forests. In wetlands, yellow birch seedlings
often become established on fallen logs. What appear
to be prop roots on mature trees are in fact locations
where the “nurse” log has decomposed out from
beneath the mature tree.

Note decomposing logs and stumps
Note decomposing logs and
stumps

Downed logs and stumps are the establishment site for the succession of decomposition communities. Moreover they are preferred habitat and movement pathways for small mammals, amphibians, etc..
Downed logs and stumps are the establishment site for
the succession of decomposition communities. Moreover
they are preferred habitat and movement pathways for
small mammals, amphibians, etc..

Often they are preferred locations for their predators as well. (e.g., Hikers’ axiom—always step on a log, not over it.)
Often they are preferred locations for their predators as well. (e.g.,
Hikers’ axiom—always step on a log, not over it.)

In their 2001 review of issues concerning wetland mitigation the National Academy of Science observed:*
In their 2001 review of issues concerning wetland mitigation the
National Academy of Science observed:*

1. Concern at meeting hydrological criteria often encouraged construction of permanently flooded open-water wetlands. 2. Compliance criteria sometimes specified plant species that site
1. Concern at meeting hydrological criteria often encouraged
construction of permanently flooded open-water wetlands.
2. Compliance criteria sometimes specified plant species that site

conditions could not support, or were unnecessary or inappropriate.
conditions could not support, or were unnecessary or
inappropriate.

In their conclusions their recommendations included:
In their conclusions their recommendations included:

1. All mitigation wetlands should be self-sustaining. 2. Biological dynamics should be evaluated in terms of populations
1. All mitigation wetlands should be self-sustaining.
2. Biological dynamics should be evaluated in terms of populations

3. Hydrological variability should be incorporated into mitigation
3. Hydrological variability should be incorporated into mitigation

present in reference models.
present in reference models.

design and evaluation.
design and evaluation.

*National Research Council. 2001. Compensating for Wetland Losses Under the Clean Water Act. National Academy Press, Washington, DC.
*National Research Council. 2001. Compensating for Wetland Losses Under the Clean
Water Act. National Academy Press, Washington, DC.

As a result of the concern to insure “adequate” hydrology many mitigation sites result in “duck donuts” even when the target is to restore wooded wetlands.
As a result of the concern to insure “adequate” hydrology many
mitigation sites result in “duck donuts” even when the target is to
restore wooded wetlands.

In an effort to experiment with the introduction of coarse woody debris, stumps were incorporated into this highway mitigation project in Delaware.
In an effort to experiment with the introduction of coarse
woody debris, stumps were incorporated into this highway
mitigation project in Delaware.

Note offset backhoe blade for ease of observation and placement of transplants.
Note offset backhoe
blade for ease of
observation and
placement of
transplants.

The US Fish and Wildlife Service in cooperation with Delaware state personnel have perfected a technique of transplanting entire trees and shrubs with their root wad intact as part of Partners in Wildlife wetland restoration projects. (Rizzo A., and Barthlemeh, T., pers. comm.)
The US Fish and
Wildlife Service in
cooperation with
Delaware state
personnel have
perfected a
technique of
transplanting entire
trees and shrubs
with their root wad
intact as part of
Partners in Wildlife
wetland restoration
projects. (Rizzo A.,
and Barthlemeh, T.,
pers. comm.)

Transplants are taken from the edge of adjacent, established wetlands and are placed at the equivalent elevation in the restored area.
Transplants are taken from the edge of adjacent, established
wetlands and are placed at the equivalent elevation in the restored
area.

“Partners in Wildlife” restoration in progress…..
“Partners in Wildlife”
restoration in progress…..

A New Model: Rather than the “plantation” approach of many wetland restoration efforts (e.g., relatively homogenous topography, hydrology and plant communities) wetland restoration practitioners may wish to mimic the ecology of forest gaps.
A New Model: Rather than the “plantation” approach of many
wetland restoration efforts (e.g., relatively homogenous topography,
hydrology and plant communities) wetland restoration practitioners
may wish to mimic the ecology of forest gaps.

First/second order coastal plain headwater wetland, Yorktown, VA
First/second order coastal plain
headwater wetland, Yorktown, VA

This Yorktown, VA wetland was most recently affected by Hurricane Isabel in September 2003 which resulted in the blow down of a significant number of canopy trees.
This Yorktown, VA wetland was most recently affected by
Hurricane Isabel in September 2003 which resulted in the blow
down of a significant number of canopy trees.

A Hypothetical New Recipe:
A Hypothetical New Recipe:

1. Locate appropriate restoration site based on landscape position,
1. Locate appropriate restoration site based on landscape position,

soils, available hydrology, reference wetland, etc.
soils, available hydrology, reference wetland, etc.

2. Establish appropriate sized “vessel” (e.g., depression, flat,
2. Establish appropriate sized “vessel” (e.g., depression, flat,

floodplain).
floodplain).

3. “Moisten” to establish requisite hydrology (e.g.,
3. “Moisten” to establish requisite hydrology (e.g.,

redirect/reestablish flow, plug ditches, break drainage tiles, establish low head berms or weirs). Care should be taken to establish appropriate heterogeneity of hydrology.
redirect/reestablish flow, plug ditches, break drainage tiles,
establish low head berms or weirs). Care should be taken to
establish appropriate heterogeneity of hydrology.

4. “Mix” (soil) vigorously (e.g., root rake, disc) until desired
4. “Mix” (soil) vigorously (e.g., root rake, disc) until desired

microtopography is established).
microtopography is established).

A Hypothetical New Recipe (cont):
A Hypothetical New Recipe (cont):

5. “Season” liberally with a mix of litter, twigs, branches and large specimens of coarse woody debris (size and volume based on reference wetland conditions).
5. “Season” liberally with a mix of litter, twigs, branches and large
specimens of coarse woody debris (size and volume based on
reference wetland conditions).

6. “Mix” in appropriate “nurse” stock of the appropriate species
6. “Mix” in appropriate “nurse” stock of the appropriate species

to provide cover/shade (e.g. Populus, Betula) and/or enhance soil (e.g. Alnus, Gleditsia). Selectively cut later at intervals if appropriate.
to provide cover/shade (e.g. Populus, Betula) and/or enhance soil
(e.g. Alnus, Gleditsia). Selectively cut later at intervals if
appropriate.

7. Plant or transplant “target” species at the appropriate time.
7. Plant or transplant “target” species at the appropriate time.

8. Monitor regularly (e.g., 1-2-3-4-5-7-9-12-15-20+) to control for invasive, nuisance species. Apply adaptive management when and where appropriate.
8. Monitor regularly (e.g., 1-2-3-4-5-7-9-12-15-20+) to control for
invasive, nuisance species. Apply adaptive management when
and where appropriate.

9. Upon successful completion “serve” to appropriate public or
9. Upon successful completion “serve” to appropriate public or

private entity.
private entity.

Thank you for your time, attention and consideration!
Thank you for your time, attention and
consideration!
